webTitle: Olympic Games: MPs challenge 'astonishing' rise in G4S bill

fields.bodyText: Embattled security group G4S has come under further pressure after MPs questioned the "astonishing" rise in the price of the contract to provide Olympic venue guards and insisted the recent humiliating debacle over numbers was predictable. In a report published on Thursday on G4S's embarrassing inability to fulfil its contract, the Commons public accounts committee said there was "no credible explanation" for the sharp increase in fees that prompted one MP to say "the first winner of an Olympic gold is G4S." As London 2012 organisers, the army and Home Office officials scramble to fill security rotas despite the deployment of 3,500 additional troops, Metropolitan police officers were on Wednesday forced to guard the Olympic venue at Lord's cricket ground because G4S guards failed to show up. About 20 police officers were bussed in at 6am on Wednesday to the north London venue where the archery competition will take place, the Guardian was told, and stayed there for 10 hours before being replaced by others. Officers were told that G4S security guards had to be replaced at short notice and that some had been found asleep, which G4S denied. Some officers were told they have to return the following day. Nine out of 12 police forces have been drafted in to help Games security. They include Strathclyde, West Midlands, Thames Valley, Greater Manchester and Dorset. A spokesman for G4S said that police officers were first invited in to Lord's on Monday because of "staffing issues". The committee said it would be undertaking its own inquiry after the Olympics, and that the Home Office needed to get a grip urgently if the Games were to pass off without further chaos. The home affairs select committee has also announced an inquiry to take place in September, calling all the main players to give evidence. The Ministry of Defence is providing 3,500 extra troops to cover shortfalls from G4S, and the military believes it may have to provide between 500 and 2,000 more personnel in the coming days. G4S agreed in December to provide 10,000 guards for the venues, rather than the 2,000 originally asked for, increasing the value of the contract by almost £200m to £284m. This included £83m to cover labour, and a 12-fold increase in management costs, from £10m to £125m. G4S also secured a 22-fold increase to cover uniforms – from £3m to £65m. Margaret Hodge, chair of the committee, said: "The chaos which has emerged over the security contract was predictable and undermines confidence in those responsible for managing the Games. "No credible explanation has been given for an astonishing 12-fold hike in management costs and G4S still has not been able to deliver. Now troops are having to be drafted in. The Home Office needs to get a grip." She said the committee was worried that G4S will still "receive substantial sums of public money without providing the contracted number of guards. Value for taxpayer's money demands G4S not only pays for all additional costs incurred by the government, but also incurs financial penalties for the failure to deliver." The committee, which has had fractious relationship with the DCMS and its permanent secretary Jonathan Stephens, also urged ministers to do a proper audit of exactly how much the Olympics had cost. The £9.3bn budget does not include the £766m paid for the Olympic Park, or the funding of elite athletes or transport improvements in London. "We have faced considerable difficulty in pinning down just how much the Games is costing the taxpayer and how much risk there is,'' said Hodge. "A big concern is that [DCMS] has no intention of producing a single auditable account for the Games, drawing together both the costs within the public sector funding package of £9.3bn and those outside. Such an analysis must be produced." David Cameron said on Wednesday he would "go after" G4S for not fulfilling its contract. Speaking during a trip to Afghanistan where he met British troops, the prime minister said: "We will go after them for the money to make sure that they help pay for the military personnel that have been brought in." The sports minister, Hugh Robertson, said the government was also looking at reducing G4S's management fee by invoking penalty clauses. However, he dismissed calls for the firm's chief executive, Nick Buckles, to resign immediately, saying the Olympics needed "stability". "What happens to Mr Buckles is a matter for others in a post-Games environment... the important thing is that we deliver a safe and secure Games, and G4S remain a key partner in that, so I want stability at that firm, and delivery. I don't want resignations causing chaos. What happens to Mr Buckles afterwards is a matter for others in the post-Games environment." The Labour leader, Ed Miliband, will on Thursday call for the government to review G4S's ability to deliver on policing contracts and for reassurance from the government that core functions such as beat patrol and criminal investigations will not be privatised. At Labour's police commissioner candidates' conference, he will say: "What has happened over G4S demands that the government rethinks its position on the role of the private sector in policing." The culture secretary, Jeremy Hunt, defended the government's position. "With just over a week to go we are on track to deliver a great Games on time and under budget. At the end of May there was £476m of contingency [money] unallocated and I am confident that we will deliver the project for under £9bn," he said. "We disagree with the Committee's assertion that the DCMS has lacked transparency. London 2012 has arguably been more transparent than any other public sector project. For example we have produced 16 financial updates to Parliament over the last four years."

webTitle: Privy council blocks 'vulture fund' from collecting $100m DRC debt

fields.standfirst: FG Hemisphere had tried to exploit a legal loophole to demand impoverished African nation pay back money
fields.body:
The privy council has blocked a multimillionaire speculator from taking up to $100m (£64m) from the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) for a decades old debt that started out at $3.3m.

Peter Grossman, who runs so-called "vulture fund" FG Hemisphere, had tried to exploit a legal loophole to demand the impoverished African nation pay back the debt. But the privy council overturned a previous court ruling allowing FG Hemisphere to demand the multimillion-pound payout from DRC's state-owned mining company.

In an attempt to skirt British law, which bans "vulture funds" from buying poor nations' debts on the cheap before suing them for 10-100 times the amount paid, Grossman took the case to Jersey, a crown dependency not covered by the UK law.

The Jersey court had ruled the DRC's state-owned mining company Gécamines should pay back the debt, which was originally a loan from the former Yugoslavia to Zaire, as DRC was then known, to build power lines 30 years ago.

Bosnian police files, shown to the Guardian and Newsnight, reveal FG Hemisphere paid $3.3m for the Yugoslav power claim. Michael Sheehan, another so-called vulture who set up the deal and who chooses to refer to himself as Goldfinger after the James Bond villain, is said to have collected more than half a million dollars from setting up the deal.

The privy council, which is the final court of appeal for Crown dependencies (including Jersey), ruled that Gécamines is not responsible for the Congolese government's debts.

The ruling means FG Hemisphere can no longer collect the debt via Jersey and the case may set a precedent making it harder for vulture funds and other sovereign debt creditors to collect funds from state-owned companies.

Before turning to the Jersey loophole, Grossman's company had unsuccessfully tried to seize the DRC's embassy in Washington as a downpayment on the debt.

A spokesman for Grossman said: "We are obviously disappointed at the judgment delivered by the council. FG Hemisphere has sought repayment of a debt for electrical infrastructure built at the request of the DRC government by a private company that was never paid for this work. We remain committed to finding a legal and fair resolution of this claim." Last year Grossman released a lengthy statement on the case, which can be read here: http://www.fghem.com/.

Justin Harvey-Hills, a partner at Mourant Ozannes, which represented Gécamines in the case, said: "The case will go far beyond Jersey and the UK. It sets an important precedent in common law. In order to enforce claims for sovereign debt against state-owned companies, creditors will need to show that the company is so much part of the state it has no meaningful independent existence."

The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank said many countries had been pursued by vulture funds, including Cameroon, Ethiopia, Sudan, Uganda, and the DRC. The IMF has said vulture funds are engaged in claims seeking a total of $1.47bn from the world's poorest countries.

webTitle: Trade minister's literary effort on money and morality may need updating | Analysis

fields.standfirst: Readers might like ex-HSBC chief executive Lord Green to explain how money-laundering controls were so lax on his watch
fields.body:
The book by Lord Green published a couple of years ago offering "reflections on money, morality and an uncertain world", requires updating.

How, his readers will want to know, could a man with such a fine sense of how capitalism can serve the needs of society have led a bank that has been accused by a US Senate committee of having a "pervasively polluted" culture that allowed drugs cartels and financiers of terrorism to launder billions of dollars?

HSBC's faults were, of course, inadvertent. All the same, Lord Green, chief executive of HSBC from 2003 to 2006 and then executive chairman until 2010, would surely want to explain how money-laundering controls could have been so lax on his watch. His former shareholders may also want to know, since HSBC faces stiff penalties, perhaps as much as $1bn (£640m). There were no answers yesterday from the current trade minister, just a firm "unavailable to comment".

The title of that book, by the way, was Good Value. A trade minister who stays in his bunker is not good value – even when the position is unpaid.

webTitle: Co-operative bank clinches deal for 632 Lloyds branches

fields.standfirst: Long-awaited on-off sale likely to be welcomed by the government, which wants to bolster banking competition
fields.body:
Lloyds Banking Group is poised to announce a formal agreement to sell 632 branches to the Co-op in a move that will create a new competitor on the high street but raise questions about the price that the bailed-out bank achieved for the branches.

The long-awaited on-off sale is expected to be clinched in the next 24 hours and will bolster the Co-op's banking presence to 1,000 branches – from 354 now, giving the mutual a 7% share of the current market.

The deal was forced on Lloyds by the EU in return for £20bn of state aid.

It is likely to be welcomed by the government which wants to bolster banking competition, particularly at a time when traditional banks are mired in controversy.

"Heads of agreement" were still being finalised Wednesday night, and while there had been hopes a year ago that the branch sale might fetch up to £1.5bn such a price tag is now believed to be unlikely.

In June Lloyds had said it was in the final phase of protracted discussions.

António Horta-Osório, the Lloyds chief executive, made achieving the sale of the branches one of his priorities when he took the helm a year ago.

The deal with the Co-op is significantly behind the original timetable because after the mutual warned in March there were "some very material regulatory issues".

The Co-op chief executive, Peter Marks, had admitted that he could not "predict whether we'll get to the end on this".

The enlarged Co-op would be cited as a major competitor to the "big four" – Lloyds, Royal Bank of Scotland, HSBC and Barclays – although the deal is likely to take another year to complete. Other new competitors include Virgin, which bought Northern Rock at the start of the year, and Marks & Spencer, which this week announced a new current account that will charge customers of the retailer.

RBS, 83% owned by the taxpayer, is also in the process of selling branches under an EU-mandated deal to Santander. That deal has also fallen behind timetable.

webTitle: Universal Music must sell more assets to acquire EMI, Brussels says

fields.standfirst: Europe's watchdog concerned that proposed $1.9bn takeover of EMI would create a behemoth with undue market power
fields.body:
Universal Music – home to Rihanna and U2 – has been told by the European Commission to offer additional concessions if the world's largest music company is to have a chance of winning regulatory approval for its £1.2bn ($1.9bn) purchase of EMI.

The failure to win over Brussels quickly takes Universal, owned by French company Vivendi and run by Briton Lucian Grainge, closer to the point where it will be forced to hand over £1.2bn to EMI's owner Citigroup – without necessarily having won the regulatory approval it needs to complete the transaction.

It is understood that the EC rejected Universal's initial package of proposed divestments, which would have resulted in it offloading Virgin Records, home to the Spice Girls, and other smaller parts of its artist roster and recorded music catalogues to win approval for the purchase.

Earlier this week, Richard Branson, who owned Virgin Records until he sold it to EMI for $1bn in 1992 indicated that he could be interested in taking control of the unit in partnership with one time business colleague, Patrick Zelnick, from Naive Records of France.

Taken together, Universal Music and EMI would account for about 40% of the music sold worldwide, in a market with only two other significant players, Sony Music and Warner Music. With such a large market position in prospect, the takeover has been scrutinised by the EC and the Federal Trade Commission in the United States.

Had the EC been sympathetic to Universal's initial offer of divestments, the regulator would have informally sounded out third parties in the industry, a process known as "market testing". But it is understood that the commission this week declined to market test the package that was on offer, prompting Universal to consider more sales of record labels or its catalogue.

Universal had hoped that it would meet an EC deadline of this week to begin the market testing process, which in turn would have given the French owned music group a chance to win regulatory approval for the EMI buyout before Brussels shuts down for the summer. However, the commission may now chose to extend its delibrations into September, creating a further headache for parent company Vivendi.

When Universal agreed to buy EMI from Citigroup in November of last year, owner Vivendi agreed that it would pay Citigroup £1.2bn 10 months later, regardless of whether it had won regulatory approval.

The deadline passes in mid-September and in theory Vivendi will have to hand money over to the US bank, although it is understood that the payment could be delayed for a period if negotiations in Brussels were close to reaching a conclusion. Citigroup ended up owning EMI after it decided to foreclose on its loans to Guy Hands's Terra Firma, after it concluded that EMI under Hands could not handle its debt load.

The prospect of handing over £1.2bn to Citigroup is particularly embarassing for Vivendi at a time when the French the future direction of the media and technology conglomerate is uncertain following the ousting of group CEO Jean-Bernard Levy. Vivendi has been conducting a strategic review, under chairman Jean Rene Fourtou, which has led to contemplate possible sales of some business units, including its majority shareholding in Activision, the computer games developer, and its Morroccan telephone business.

Negotiations between the EC and Universal are understood to be continuing.

webTitle: AEA Technology survival in doubt as trustees disagree over £34m debt

fields.standfirst: UK Atomic Energy Authority spin-off valued lower than £1m as it records pension liabilities of £165m and bank funding crisis
fields.body:
An environmental consultancy spun out of the UK Atomic Energy Authority as one of the last privatisations by John Major's government was fighting for survival on Wednesday with pension liabilities exceeding £165m and no long-term bank funding.

The company, AEA Technology, which works for many UK and American government departments, said it was considering "all strategic options to realise value" but made clear that investors faced significant losses.

"The board does not envisage there will be offers for the share capital of the company and the board expects that such options will result in little or no value for shareholders," it said in a statement to the London Stock Exchange. Shares in the company, which is chaired by the former E.ON chief executive Paul Golby, plunged by more than 80%, leaving a business that was once valued at £566m now worth less than £1m.

AEA, which has premises at Harwell, Oxfordshire, said Lloyds Banking Group and pension trustees had been supportive but were unable to agree on a long-term solution to its £34m debt and pension problems. Further short-term financing had been made available and all sides were trying to find a way of keeping the business running.

The company, which describes itself as "one of the world's leading energy and climate-change consultancies", has been through significant changes of fortune since it was first separated from the UK Atomic Energy Authority in 1994 then floated two years later.

The firm originally helped with decommissioning nuclear facilities but moved into various other areas.

The shares were issued in 1996 at 228p, raising £228m, but within 18 months their value had soared to 662p triggering an investigation by the National Audit Office. The NAO strongly criticised Schroders and Cazenove, financial advisers to the former Department of Trade and Industry, for selling off the business too cheaply.

Private-sector advisers made more than £8m from the float. The chief executive was Peter Watson, a former chairman of the privatised train leasing company Porterbrook, who made £3m from the sale of that business to Stagecoach.

Watson led AEA until 2005 when he was turfed out in a boardroom coup after failing to make money out of diversifying AEA into a rail consultancy, triggering two profit warnings.

He was replaced as chief executive by the former managing director Andrew McCree, who was shown the door last November after issuing two profit warnings in seven months.

AEA had sold off its nuclear technology and engineering software businesses and in recent years moved into advising on energy and climate change.

The company was a lead contractor on Boris Johnson's carbon reduction scheme for big businesses in London; staff also worked on environmental issues for the government.

It also made two strategic acquisitions, taking it into the US. But public-sector cutbacks on both sides of the Atlantic left it in financial trouble.

The company was on Wednesday unwilling to speak further about its prospects. "We all agreed there were few questions we could answer sensibly today, so we are making no comment," said a spokesman.

The formal statement said the company had a plan which set out a "positive way forward" and which had already started to improve the AEA's operating efficiency.

webTitle: HSBC money laundering scandal draws in trade minister

fields.standfirst: Lord Green, former CEO and chair of HSBC, warned he has 'serious questions' to answer as bank awaits details of US fine
fields.body:
The trade minister, Lord Green, has been drawn in to the HSBC money laundering scandal after Labour warned he had "serious questions" to answer about the way the bank laundered money for drug cartels, terrorists and pariah states while he was at the helm.

Green was chief executive of Britain's biggest bank between 2003 and 2006 and was its chairman until 2010 when he resigned to take up a position of trade minister in the coalition government.

A damning Senate report - which concluded the bank had a "pervasively polluted" culture - covers the period 2004 to 2010 and shows that HSBC subsidiaries moved billions of dollars around the financial system from countries such as Iran and Syria as well moving cash for Mexican drug cartels.

An example of an email reproduced in the report appears to show that Green was warned by HSBC's head of compliance David Bagley - who dramatically resigned during Tuesday's appearance before Senators - to alert him to a potential breach to the rules in relation to sanctions in trading with Burma. Bagley wrote there is a "significant risk of financial penalty" as there is "little doubt that it is a breach" of the sanctions (which were lifted in May this year). The report found that a new internal policy was introduced afterwards, but that transactions continued to occur.

The report also shows that executives set up internal reviews to try to tackle the problems and referred themselves to the regulatory body.

Chris Leslie, Labour's the shadow financial secretary to the Treasury, said on Wednesday: "The US Senate sub-committee's report, which suggests that HSBC allowed money laundering by drug cartels and possibly even terrorists, is so serious that the bank's head of compliance has already resigned.".

"Stephen Green, who was executive chairman of the bank when this took place and is now a trade minister in David Cameron's government, now has serious questions to answer about what he knew and when," said Leslie

With the Commons in recess for the summer, Labour's leader in the Lords, Baroness Royall, tabled an urgent question to force a statement about Green's involvement but the request was rejected by Lords Speaker Baroness D'Souza.

Green, who is also an advisor to the government on banks, was not available for comment following Leslie's remarks. A respected banking figure, who has been cited as potential candidate to be the next governor of the Bank of England, Green was also chairman of the British Bankers' Association during the time of the Libor-rigging scandal that led to the £290m fine on Barclays and the departure of chief executive bob Diamond.

Labour was quick to call on Green to answer questions following the intense pressure that shadow chancellor Ed Balls faced from George Osborne following the Libor scandal which at one point risked drawing in former Labour ministers.

Bagley's dramatic resignation during the Senate hearing on Tuesday, came as Paul Thurston, currently chief executive of retail banking and wealth management and former head of the UK bankat HSBC, and head of the Mexican banking business in 2007 and told Ssenators he was "horrified" by what he found.

HSBC has been quick to apologise for the failings and Bagley told senators Carl Levin and Tom Coburn that: "HSBC has fallen short of our own expectations and the expectations of our regulators."

Danny Alexander, chief secretary to the Treasury, told the Today programme that the issues stemmed from the past: "This is a reminder of the huge difficulties our banking system got into in the run-up to the banking crisis, the culture that existed then that led to all sorts of appalling and irresponsible behaviour from which this country is still suffering under the weight of the consequences from those mistakes," Alexander said.

Labour peer Lord Foulkes claimed Lord Green was too "embarrassed" about his record to answer questions in Parliament.

In the spotlight

Aside from Lord Green, questions about the money laundering saga could also be asked of Sir John Bond, who was chairman of HSBC until May 2006 when he retired after 45 years with the bank when we was succeeded by Green. Bond has been chairman of Xstrata since May 2011 and was chairman of Vodafone until July 2011. Michael Geoghegan took over from Green as chief executive in May 2006, one of many assignments he had since joining the bank in 1973. He left in 2010 when Green's departure caused a boardroom tussle. Another long-standing HSBC executive Sandy Flockhart ran the Mexican operations from 2002 to 2006 but after a 37 year career his retirement from the bank was announced earlier this month to fight cancer. The current chairman Douglas Flint was finance director during the period.

webTitle: Laura Ashley blooms again as retailer reports £18.8m annual profits

fields.standfirst: Turnaround in fortunes for 'heritage' label famous for its floral prints, partly attributed to collaboration with Uniqlo
fields.body:
It was once described as the fashion label that made British women dress as milkmaids, then in the late 1990s went to the verge of collapse as its floral prints fell out of favour with consumers, but Laura Ashley seems to be blooming again. This year the retailer reported a 4.1 % increase in UK retail sales in the first 18 weeks of the financial year, with profits of £18.8m on sales of £285.9m; quite a turnaround for a label that reported an annual loss of £17m in 1998.

Its Uniqlo collaboration has put Laura Ashley back on the fashion radar, with the fashion blogger Liberty London Girl among those singing its praises. "Uniqlo have launched lots of different collaborations, from J+ Jil Sander to Hello Kitty, but this has to be my favourite so far, tapping into both this summer's major floral trend, and a particular brand of British nostalgia," she wrote.

Melanie Rickey, fashion editor at large at Grazia magazine, who blogs at fashioneditoratlarge.com, said the Uniqlo partnership was "a really interesting collaboration for them. Laura Ashley won't be troubling anyone with its cool status any time soon. However, they have targeted their core market successfully, namely the aspiring English country home owner, and have decent homewares and furniture as well as a significant textile heritage. They could be the Liberty of the high street".

The brand, which started in 1953, after its eponymous founder's 19th-century style printed Victorian headscarves became popular, credits two factors for its success in bucking the downward trend amongst retailers: a focus on furniture and a move towards e-commerce.

Website sales are up 18.8% year-on-year, and some say its familiar aesthetic has been appealing in a time of economic turmoil. "One of the symptoms of the current economic climate is that people are a little bit more conservative in their approach to decorating," said Giles Kime, deputy editor of Homes and Gardens magazine. "Before, if there had been a lot of money around, you might have bought an item of furniture that was quite a dramatic fashion statement, whereas now you are taking a longer term view – you'll be taking a more centrist approach. Laura Ashley wallpapers and fabrics allow people to create a new look without massive investment."

The website offers a cheap bespoke service, which allows customers to buy furniture in a choice of more than 100 fabrics. There is also an "outlet" service, run by the retailer through eBay, which offers up to 50% off some furniture lines. Laura Ashley closed its Oxford Circus branch in 2005, but it still has 200 stores in the UK and another 250 worldwide, which analysts suggest have helped online sales.

Bill Webb, a retail expert from the London College of Fashion, said: "Homeware lends itself very well to e-commerce because you can't carry most of the larger products away. Laura Ashley has used a successful techniquethat we call cross-channel operations where they have integrated the physical shop as more of a brand showroom where people can bounce on the beds, ask for advice, touch and look at products, then order online and wait for delivery later at home."

Like many British heritage brands, Laura Ashley faces the challenge of retaining its core customers while attracting new ones. Last month, Burberry posted pre-tax profits up 24% to £366m, with sales also up 24% to £1.86bn. By contrast, Aquascutum went bust in April. Habitat, a company which might be considered a contemporary of Laura Ashley, having been set up by Sir Terence Conran in 1964, went into administration in June last year.

"Staying relevant is the key word," said Liz Mouat, Laura Ashley's head of buying for home. "We have a customer that has been shopping with us for generations that we absolutely need to retain, harness and delight. Now, their children are shopping, but they don't necessarily want the same things."

There are still many people who would not dream of visiting a store to buy clothing, but Laura Ashley is reaching some of them through its collaborations. In 2011 it partnered the ethical clothing brand People Tree. This year, it was one of three designers chosen by Uniqlo for a range designed to showcase British heritage brands, lining up alongside Orla Kiely and Lulu Guinness.

"The combination of Laura Ashley vintage prints with Uniqlo's modern, innovative materials allowed for us to create a very successful and commercial collection that appealed to both young and old," said a spokesman for Uniqlo.

Nick Kaloyirou, joint chief operating officer of Laura Ashley, described the collaboration as "a perfect opportunity to introduce Laura Ashley to a new demographic of customer and allowing us to use our archive in a contemporary way."Laura Ashley originally sold via mail order and through stores such as John Lewis. Its first London shop opened in 1968, its prints happily coinciding with contemporary hippy tastes in Victoriana. The firm expanded throughout the 70s and 80s, when shops opened across the UK and abroad, but by the late 90s the brand dominated high streets, and its trademark floral prints began to be derided as old-fashioned. Sales fell and it came to the brink of administration before it was saved by a Malaysian conglomerate who injected £44m.

The brand's business model changed in the early 2000s, with the launch of 17 standalone home-furnishing shops. "Home furnishings is really what is driving our business and where our real growth is coming from," said Mouat. This year, the company will open two gift shops in St Albans and Canterbury to add to the one in London, and announced that it would open a Laura Ashley hotel decorated in its designs in Hertfordshire.

webTitle: Russian oligarchs fire warning shot to BP over TNK-BP's future

fields.standfirst: Alfa Access Renova (AAR), the group of oligarchs who own half of the business, formally told BP it wanted to enter into discussions over the future of BP's stake in the joint venture
fields.body:
A fresh dispute between Russian oligarchs and BP over the TNK-BP business opened up on Wednesday over the future of the Siberian oil business.

Alfa Access Renova (AAR), the group of oligarchs who own half of the business, formally told BP it wanted to enter into discussions over the future of BP's stake in the joint venture to end the "internal contradictions" at TNK-BP.

It went on to warn the UK company that legal action over a separate compensation claim would go on while saying TNK-BP now provided 90% of BP group dividends, a claim BP described as "absurd".

The 50/50 owners of the Russian oil group have been in conflict over the future corporate direction for many years with the Russians wanting to turn it into a global business.

On 1 June BP announced it had received a number of unsolicited offers for its stake and said it planned to pursue talks. A 45-day notice period under which AAR had to register its desire to hold negotiations was due to expire on Wednesday triggering the formal expression of interest.

"AAR and BP both realise that a fundamental realignment in the ownership of TNK-BP is necessary in order to allow each of the shareholders to achieve its strategic objectives and eliminate the internal contradictions that are preventing further development of TNK-BP," said Stan Polovets, chief executive of of AAR.

AAR, which would also consider selling its stake to BP if agreement on price could be found, said TNK-BP provided $3.7bn (£2.36bn) out of BP's total dividend of $4.1bn (£2.62bn) in 2011.

The oligarchs also said that TNK-BP production performance was substantially better than BP in the first quarter of 2012. TNK-BP production volume grew 4% whilst production volume of BP's other assets declined by 6%, it noted.

A BP spokesman said the dividend figures were technically correct but a false comparison was being made: "It is absurd. You cannot make a direct link between these (numbers)."

The official added that the production figures were distorted by BP's recent asset sales and fall in Gulf of Mexico output in the aftermath of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

AAR said a sale by BP of all or any part of its interest in TNK-BP would not affect "BP's potential liability to AAR" for breach of the shareholders' agreement in connection with BP's attempted strategic alliance with rival Russian firm, Rosneft.

webTitle: IMF calls for 'decisive action' as Spanish bond yields near danger level

fields.standfirst: ECB must cut interest rates, start large-scale QE and wade into bond markets to drive down borrowing costs, says critical report
fields.body:
The International Monetary Fund has warned the eurozone's leaders to take "decisive action" as Spanish bond yields shot up to dangerous levels, signalling a fresh leg of the sovereign debt crisis.

In its annual report on the eurozone's policies, known as an Article IV, the IMF made clear that it believes euro ministers have not yet done enough to underpin the future of the single currency.

It called for the European Central Bank to cut interest rates, implement a "sizeable" package of quantitative easing, and wade into bond markets to drive down borrowing costs.

Madrid saw its 10-year bond yields – a proxy for how much the government must pay to borrow – hit 6.94% on Wednesday, close to the 7% level that many analysts consider to be unsustainable.

Spain received a €100bn (£78bn) bailout for its banking sector last month, and its prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, was regarded as having won a good deal from Germany in avoiding the painful conditions attached to rescue loans for Greece, Portugal and Ireland.

But since he announced €65bn-worth of fresh spending cuts and tax rises last week, analysts have been slashing their Spanish growth forecasts and fretting about whether it will eventually need a full-blown bailout.

The German finance minister, Wolfgang Schaüble, stoked the fearful mood, saying in an interview with the Rheiniche Post that Spain remained ultimately responsible for meeting the bank rescue costs.

The IMF expressed concern about "reinforced negative bank-sovereign linkages" – the increasingly close connection between struggling banks, many sitting on billions of euros of government bonds; and their home states, which in many cases have been forced to offer them aid.

This vicious circle "could further weigh on confidence, growth, and public debt trajectories", the IMF suggested.

As Spain's borrowing costs rose, Germany was able to borrow money at a negative real yield – suggesting investors are effectively willing to pay Berlin for holding on to their cash.

In its strongly worded report, the IMF warned that ultra-low bond yields in Germany and other "core" eurozone economies were a sign of malfunctioning financial markets that are depriving other countries of funds.

"Investors are withholding funding from member states most in need, moving capital 'north' and abroad to perceived safer assets. This has contributed to divergences in liquidity conditions and lending rates within the euro area, adding to already-severe pressures on many bank and sovereign balance sheets and raising questions about the viability of the monetary union itself," it said.

The newly elected Greek government, which came to power promising to win a better deal from the country's creditors, is struggling to agree €11.5bn-worth of cuts being demanded by the troika of the ECB, IMF and European commission which are due in Athens next week.

Grreece's finance minister, Yiannis Stournaras, emerged from fraught talks with fellow ministers on Wednesday night, saying: "We still don't have concrete measures." Athens has said that it will seek a short-term bridging loan from eurozone partners to tide it over the summer months, while it tries to convince the troika to release the next tranche of its €130bn bailout.

Alexis Tsipras, the leader of Greece's far-left Syriza opposition party, accused the governing coalition of drawing up a "catastrophic plan" of more painful austerity measures. "The government is executing orders from the troika and is not serving the public interest," he said.

The IMF warned that it expects the eurozone economy to contract by 0.3% this year, and eke out growth of just 0.7% in 2013; but even this may prove too optimistic, because there are, "severe downside risks to the outlook, with possible substantial regional and global implications".

This vicious circle "could further weigh on confidence, growth, and public debt trajectories", the IMF suggested. As Spain's borrowing costs rose, Germany was able to borrow money at a negative real yield – suggesting investors are effectively willing to pay Berlin for holding on to their cash. "Investors are withholding funding from member states most in need, moving capital 'north' and abroad to perceived safer assets. The newly elected Greek government, which came to power promising to win a better deal from the country's creditors, is struggling to agree €11.5bn-worth of cuts being demanded by the troika of the ECB, IMF and European commission which are due in Athens next week. Alexis Tsipras, the leader of Greece's far-left Syriza opposition party, accused the governing coalition of drawing up a "catastrophic plan" of more painful austerity measures. The IMF warned that it expects the eurozone economy to contract by 0.3% this year, and eke out growth of just 0.7% in 2013; but even this may prove too optimistic, because there are, "severe downside risks to the outlook, with possible substantial regional and global implications".

webTitle: Bond yields spell return of the eurozone crisis

fields.bodyText: It was only a month ago that the financial world was full of talk that German bunds might not, after all, be the definition of a safe haven. Yields on 10-year bunds had been 1.2% on 1 June but hit 1.6% on the 20th. Two explanations were offered. First, investors were understandably nervous about locking in a miserable yield of 1.2% for a decade. Second, there was the thought that Germany would always blink in the euro crisis, agreeing to underwrite greater proportions of its neighbours' debts even if the process were dragged out over many years. The inevitable consequence of propping up the eurozone, it was felt, would be a rise in Germany's cost of borrowing. So much for that theory. Plunging yields on "safe haven" sovereign debt are back with force. On the 10-year, German yields stand at 1.2% again; over two years, investors are willing to suffer negative yields for the privilege of lending to Germany. The search for havens has swept up the UK and the US, where 10-year yields fell below 1.5% on Wednesday. What's more, UK 10-year gilt yields were actually marginally lower than on the equivalent US treasuries, perhaps reflecting the idea that the Bank of England currently looks keener than the US Federal Reserve to indulge in more quantitative easing, aka money-printing. What's going on? It seems to be the familiar explanation: brief excitement after the appearance of the eurozone's latest painkiller, in this case the bailout of Spain's banks, has been replaced by the realisation that nothing substantial has changed. In fact, the position may have worsened. The true nature of the Spanish bargain is now clear - the government in Madrid has adopted a massive austerity package in order to escape an official bailout. Such (dubious) virtue has brought no reward: Spanish 10-year yields are once again within a whisker of 7%. That, unfortunately, is no surprise. On the International Monetary Fund's forecasts, Spain will remain in recession next year - and a further heavy dose of spending cuts and pay freezes won't help. The net result is that the euro crisis has crawled out of the box again. HSBC, Barclays and G4S entertained us with their shenanigans, but now it's back to the euro slog. What's the next stage? Nobody knows, but Gary Jenkins of Swordfish Research makes a fair point when he argues that there is now a "career risk" for the average fixed-income fund manager in holding Spanish and Italian bonds. Their presence in a discretionary portfolio has become hard to explain to clients. The psychology is simple: in the disaster scenario of a eurozone break-up, you won't lose your job if you own German debt, but you will if you are over-burdened with Spanish and Italian IOUs. That leaves only Italian and Spanish banks as the natural buyers of Italian and Spanish debt. In the Spanish case, though, buying power is gradually weakening because the institutions are already stuffed to the brim with their sovereign's paper. What's the European Central Bank going to do? One theory is that, in the hope of stimulating economic activity, it might penalise banks for holding deposits centrally. For your average bond investor, though, that sounds like yet another reason to park money in expensive German bunds. And so the spiral goes on. Coming soon: the next eurozone crisis summit.

webTitle: Wet weather proves a washout for sales of summer products

fields.standfirst: Summer rains have led to changes in the spending patterns on the high street with much seasonal stock still on the shelves
fields.body:
Fashion

Clothes retailers have had to slash their prices to shift shorts, summer dresses, skirts and T-shirts. Coats, jackets and tights have been the strongest performers in the last few weeks. Marks & Spencer sold 105,000 summer jumpers between April and June, up 24% on last year, but 500,000 fewer linen garments for women, sales of which were down 28%.

Shoe retailers have seen storming sales of wellies but have been stuck with sandals. At B&Q, sales of garden footwear such as wellington boots and rubber shoes are up 97%. Shoe Zone has sold more than 115,000 pairs of wellies since the start of May – and a pair every 30 seconds since the beginning of this month.

Naomi Shefford, its marketing and property director, said: "It's a shame high summer lines are still sitting on the shelves. We've had a great reaction to our welly boots range. Sales have been driven by muddy festivals, but it seems more and more people are wearing them every day now too."

Personal care

Torrential rain drove inflation to the lowest level since November 2009 in June, partly driven by slow sales and discounting on personal care products, "notably deodorant and sunscreen," according to the Office for National Statistics.

John Lewis reports sales of fake tan up more than 20% on last year's levels, while sun cream is down 13%. Superdrug says demand for hay fever medication is down, but sales of cough and cold remedies are up.

As people stay home more, sales of home pampering products such as face masks are selling well, as are sales of vibrators and condoms. "The weather forecast is looking better next week so perhaps sales will perform a dramatic U-turn," said a spokeswoman.

Homeware

Slug pellets, heaters, grass trimmers and umbrellas are flying off the shelves, while garden furniture, barbecues and hosepipes have been almost impossible to shift. B&Q owner, Kingfisher - which will update the market on recent trade on Thursday - said bad weather hit profits by £29m in its first quarter, while Homebase suffered an 8% fall drop in like-for-like sales.

The wet warm weather has been perfect growing weather for slugs and B&Q sold 187 tonnes of slug pellets since May, up 51% on a year ago. Homebase is also selling more rotary lawn mowers and grass trimmers due to faster-growing grass, as well as greenhouse heaters and gazebos - as some hardy souls refuse to let rain stop play.

Not surprisingly, sales of umbrellas are up 500% at Superdrug. John Lewis said it had sold more brollies so far this year than any other summer. The department store also shifted 70% more heaters and 76% more tumble dryers last week. JJB Sports found golf, cricket and tennis gear a hard sell in the 22 weeks to July, when like-for-like sales dropped 8%.

Food

Barbecues are out and roast dinners in, as Britons head indoors to escape the miserable summer weather. Sainsbury's said sales of roasting joints surged 176% last week, compared with the same week last year. But, they say, customers are determined to enjoy summer treats and strawberries remain one of their most popular products.

Tesco customers, meanwhile, are cooking spicy food to make up for the cooler weather outside. Sales of searing hot Scotch Bonnet chillies shot up by 145% last week. Root vegetables were also in demand as Britons got out their casserole pots for warming winter food. Sales of baked potatoes jumped 92% and swedes were up 23%.

But Britons are having to buy funny-looking vegetables as a result of the weather. Waitrose said this week it would support farmers through one of the wettest seasons on record by accepting "cosmetically imperfect" fruit and veg, such as "shorter carrots, thinner parsnips or smaller strawberries than usual".

Travel

British travel agents have reported a 20% rise in holiday searches in June compared with last year. ABTA, the travel trade group, estimates that up to 13 million UK holidaymakers will head overseas in July and August, with 90% going to the Mediterranean in search of the silver lining of the eurozone crisis – cheaper foreign stays. A pound now buys €1.28, compared with €1.14 a year ago.

But with most people still to take their main holiday and last-minute booking becoming common practice, Britain's tourism industry says it is too early to tell how the weather will affect it.

Sarah Long, of Visit England, said: "According to our business confidence monitor, trade was down in May and June when the weather wasn't great but operators were still confident for the summer. The trend to book late is still very strong, so fingers crossed it will get better." Many regions are heavily promoting their indoor attractions.

The Olympics effect has hit inbound tourism more than any rain: many businesses reported bookings down by 30-40% for this summer with foreign visitors put off by the prospect of higher prices and overcrowding. VisitBritain said its research shows that the exceptionally rainy weather barely figures in visitors' thinking – because most believe they are set for a wet stay anyway.

webTitle: FTSE lifted by hopes of central bank moves, but Land Securities and Hammerson hit by downgrades

fields.standfirst: Property companies cut by Barclays analysts, bucking rising market trend
fields.body:
Property groups Land Securities and Hammerson have been undermined by a downgrade from analysts at Barclays.

The bank cut Land Securities, down 6p at 775p, from overweight to equalweight following its strong performance over the year so far. It made a similar cut to Hammerson, 3p lower at 464p. But the prospect of good growth in the West End of London meant Barclays boosted Capital Shopping Centres Group, up 7.9p to 335.3p, and Shaftsbury, 9.5p better at 543p.

Overall the market moved higher on hopes for further action from central banks to boost the flagging global economy. US Federal Reserve chairman Ben Bernanke may not have been too forthcoming about the prospects of a further round of quantitative easing, but neither did he rule it out. And the Bank of England's latest minutes showed the rate setting committee had considered a further interest rate cut. With UK unemployment falling and no new horrors from the eurozone, the FTSE 100 finished 56.68 points higher at 5685.77.

Some good news for the UK today as the rate of unemployment fell for the second time this year showing that even if official growth figures show the economy is in recession businesses are in better shape than the GDP data might suggest and new jobs are being created. The FTSE was also supported by BOE minutes that showed the MPC is actively considering a further interest rate cut to try and kick start the economy.

Reed Elsevier was the biggest faller in the FTSE 100 after the European Commission backed calls for free access to publicly funded research.

The publisher lost 8.5p to 524.5p in the wake of the EC comments on Tuesday, given it charges subscriptions for its 2000 journals and would seem to be vulnerable to freely available research. But analysts at Exane BNP Paribas said the EU policy was a damp squib:

[It] is unlikely to have any impact on publishers' revenues in the next ten years. The EU is a small player in global research funding - it funds an estimated 8% of all public research spending in the EU27, or less than 3% of global scientific literature.

Elsewhere, Severn Trent added 15p to $17.19 after an in-line trading statement, but rival United Utilities dipped 2p to 696p.

Imperial Tobacco lost 11p to £25.34 but this was more than explained by the company's shares going ex-dividend. However it should be noted that cash and carry group Booker, up 3.65p at 89.9p, warned that tobacco sales had fallen 1.7% in its first quarter following the rise in duty unveiled at the last UK budget.

Homeserve, the insurance and repairs company being investigated by the Financial Services Authority for alleged misselling, jumped nearly 12% despite saying it was not in talks about an offer for the business.

The statement followed a report that Cinven, KKR and Apax had approached Homeserve, although the approach was said to have been dismissed as opportunistic, given recent falls in the company's share price. It was also suggested that chief executive Richard Halpin had been approached about selling his 12% stake. Homeserve said:

Homeserve wishes to clarify that it has not, nor is currently, engaged in any discussions which could lead to a possible offer for the company.

Even so, its shares jumped 20p to 187p as investors decided it could still be vulnerable to a bid, even though analysts were not so sure. David Brockton at Espirito Santo said:

We continue to view Homeserve's international growth opportunity, supported by its low capital intensive model with a high recurring income base to present an attractive business model. However, the FSA investigation brings Homeserve further material risk of reputational damage and a lengthier than expected review process.
Our 210p fair value is materially above the current volatile share price, but there remains a wide range of possible regulatory outcomes hence we expect the shares to continue trade below the perceived inherent value of the business, particularly now that we know management are not willing to entertain any opportunistic approach for the company.

Weir, down 11p at £14.91, was hit by Nomura beginning coverage of the company with a reduce recommendation.

But G4S recovered 6p to 246p on vague talk the troubled security firm could be vulnerable to a bid, perhaps from a US rival, after its recent share price slump following its Olympics fiasco.

webTitle: Jobless total drops to 2.85m but unions say Olympics is temporary prop

fields.bodyText: A 65,000 drop in the number of people without a job has been hailed by ministers as "a step in the right direction", but Labour and trades unions warned that short-term hiring for the Olympics was masking the economy's underlying weakness. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said the number of people looking for work had fallen to 2.58 million in the three months to May, driving the unemployment rate down to 8.1% from 8.3% three months earlier. It said, however, the strong performance of London – with the capital registering 61,000 more people in employment over the period – could indicate the effect of the 2012 Olympics. A furious public spat erupted between the employment minister, Chris Grayling, and his Labour shadow, Liam Byrne, at the announcement. Byrne said the fall in unemployment was good news, but he cited claimant count numbers showing that long-term unemployment for young people had quadrupled over the past year. Grayling insisted that rise was due to the abolition of Labour schemes, such as the Future Jobs Fund, which had kept young people on training allowances instead of the dole. "I cannot understand why you continue to deliberately misuse these figures," Grayling said in a public letter to Byrne. "As both I and Iain Duncan Smith have explained the position to you many times now, I can only assume that you are deliberately trying to scaremonger." Dave Prentis, general secretary of Unison, said long-term unemployment across the economy remained high, and temporary Olympics jobs would not solve the jobs crisis. He said: "The Olympic effect may give the impression of a recovery, but it is a mirage. The number of the long-term unemployed is still rising, and huge numbers of women and young people are still struggling to find work." The ONS figures show that 441,000 people have been out of a job for more than two years. Tom Hadley, of the Recruitment and Employment Confederation, said the unemployment rate was likely to veer about in the coming months. "Tens of thousands of university, school and college leavers will be entering the job market over the summer and our latest data from recruiters shows hiring activity is slowing. The UK is making gradual progress out of recession and is likely to experience a zig-zag pattern with some good months followed by weaker ones," Hadley said. The more timely claimant-count measure of unemployment, which tracks the numbers receiving jobseeker's allowance (JSA), gave a conflicting signal: the numbers rose by 6,100 in June to a total of 1.6 million. However, the ONS said that tally could have been boosted by changes to the benefits regime for lone parents and incapacity benefit claimants, some of whom have been shifted to out-of-work benefits to bring them into the labour force. The number of women claiming JSA increased by 8,000 to 530,700, the highest level since 1995, and the ONS said the rise was likely to have been partly driven by the benefits rule changes. Youth unemployment, which the coalition government has sought to tackle through Nick Clegg's "youth contract", had fallen by 10,000, the ONS said. The jobless rate for 16- to 24-year-olds slipped to 21.9% in the three months to May from 22.1% three months earlier. The upbeat news about the labour market came as it emerged that two members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) dissented from the bank's decision to boost quantitative easing – the emergency policy of creating money to buy government bonds. Minutes of the nine-member MPC's July meeting – at which the committee opted to raise quantitative easing to £375bn to offset the turmoil in the economy – showed that the bank's chief economist, Spencer Dale, and Ben Broadbent, a former Goldman Sachs analyst, thought the move unnecessary. The minutes also showed that the MPC's members intended to reconsider the possibility of cutting interest rates from the record low of 0.5%, depending on the effectiveness of the government's Funding for Lending scheme, which offers low-cost loans to banks on condition they pass on the money to businesses and home buyers. The MPC said: "Overall, there were reasons to believe that the scheme would provide a material economic stimulus. But it was too early to judge with any precision what the economic impact would be and when it might be felt."

A furious public spat erupted between the employment minister, Chris Grayling, and his Labour shadow, Liam Byrne, at the announcement.

Byrne said the fall in unemployment was good news, but he cited claimant count numbers showing that long-term unemployment for young people had quadrupled over the past year.

Grayling insisted that rise was due to the abolition of Labour schemes, such as the Future Jobs Fund, which had kept young people on training allowances instead of the dole.

"I cannot understand why you continue to deliberately misuse these figures," Grayling said in a public letter to Byrne. "As both I and Iain Duncan Smith have explained the position to you many times now, I can only assume that you are deliberately trying to scaremonger."

He said: "The Olympic effect may give the impression of a recovery, but it is a mirage. The number of the long-term unemployed is still rising, and huge numbers of women and young people are still struggling to find work."

The ONS figures show that 441,000 people have been out of a job for more than two years.

Tom Hadley, of the Recruitment and Employment Confederation, said the unemployment rate was likely to veer about in the coming months.

The more timely claimant-count measure of unemployment, which tracks the numbers receiving jobseeker's allowance (JSA), gave a conflicting signal: the numbers rose by 6,100 in June to a total of 1.6 million.

webTitle: Bonds investors see UK as safer market than US

fields.bodyText: The UK is now a safer haven than the US, according to the bond markets. Investors looking for safe places to put their money today drove the price of 10-year UK government bonds higher, pushing yields down to 1.47%. That is a touch lower than the US 10-year government bond at 1.48%, suggesting investors now consider the UK safer than the US. The move comes after minutes from the latest meeting of the monetary policy committee meeting showed that the Bank of England considered boosting the quantitative easing (QE) programme by more than the £50bn it finally settled on two weeks ago. QE involves buying up UK government bonds, or gilts, which drives the price of gilts higher, pushing yields lower. That contrasts with the US, where Fed chairman Ben Bernanke fended off questions on Tuesday about whether the US central bank will offer a fresh round of monetary stimulus. Analysts said markets also react less to UK data than US data. Gary Jenkins of Swordfish Research says: "Maybe the UK is just less important, maybe it benefits from the fact that every single piece of US data is analysed to death and, to a degree, the UK is slightly off the radar screen." The fall in the bond yield will be welcome news for chancellor George Osborne because it lowers the rate at which the UK can borrow money and Jenkins said he deserved a small amount of credit for the UK still being considered a safe haven. "I suppose you have had some governments who have said we're going to carry on spending and they destroyed their credibility in the bond market very quickly. You could give [the government] credit for that." But he said there were more important factors at play, such as the fact that the UK has hundreds of years of history repaying its debts, has its own currency and a central bank willing to engage in quantitative easing, which reached a total of £375bn. Elsewhere in Europe, short-term bond yields have slipped into negative territory in six countries. Investors are, in effect, paying Germany, Finland, Denmark, Switzerland, the Netherlands and, most recently, Austria to lend them money for two years or less. In contrast, Spanish bond yields are moving towards the dangerous 7% mark and Italian bond yields are over 6%. Jenkins said this huge divergence in bond yields in Europe was very concerning. "It doesn't make a lot of sense investing for a negative return. It makes more sense than putting it somewhere where you are worried that you wake up in the morning and find you've lost 25% of your capital. The negative yield story is a sign of people giving up hope on the fact that anything's going to happen in the short-term to turn it around." Investors are also betting on the possibility of a break-up of the euro. Mark Dowding, senior portfolio manager at credit hedge fund BlueBay Asset Management, explains: "Arguably if you are buying a bond with a negative yield you are guaranteeing you get back less than you are paying for it in the first place. Your only chance of making a profit is in the hope you make a foreign exchange gain. The Danish krone is pegged to the euro. In a way, you are prepared to buy Danish bonds with a negative yield in the hope of the euro breaking up and the Danish krone going up in value versus the euro."

webTitle: Insurers face £500m bill for floods

fields.bodyText: Insurers are set to pay up to £500m to customers who have suffered flood and storm damage during one of Britain's wettest summers on record, according to the Association of British Insurers (ABI). The industry body said the £17m-a-day losses were the worst since the summer of 2007, when flash floods landed insurers with a £2.5bn bill. The insurer RSA has taken a £50m hit from this summer's washout. The owner of the More Than brand said on Wednesday it had received more than 6,500 claims on UK home, motor and commercial property insurance and suffered a £40m loss as a result in June. It has taken a further £10m hit from the deluge since the start of July. Nearly 40% of the claims have been settled so far. Nick Starling, the ABI's director of general insurance, said: "The widespread floods of this summer highlight how vital flood insurance is. During June alone, insurers helped 68,000 customers hit by the floods and storms." The industry is trying to hammer out a new flood agreement with the government, without which some homes in high-risk areas could be left without cover after next June, when the current agreement runs out. Analysts have warned that home insurance premiums, which are already rising, could go up further in the wake of the heavy rainfall. The areas worst affected by the storms, flooding and hail stones the size of golf balls are the east Midlands, the north-east and the north-west. RSA and its bigger rival Aviva face the biggest losses from storm damage. Barrie Cornes, insurance analyst at Panmure Gordon, said the cost to RSA was much higher than the £8m to £15m he had pencilled in, and blamed losses in commercial insurance as well as motor. He cut his annual earnings per share forecast for RSA by 14% to 11.98p. The total of RSA's losses from "acts of God" this summer is £85m after the company, which operates in 140 countries and employs 23,000 people, added that two earthquakes in the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy in May resulted in a further £35m loss. RSA has a 7% slice of the UK home insurance market and controls 15% of the commercial property market, with the losses split broadly equally between the two, plus a bit extra in motor cover, analysts estimate. Oliver Steel, insurance analyst at Deutsche Bank, said: "RSA's losses would imply a total industry cost of the June/July storms combined of £450m." Based on Aviva's market shares of 11% for household and 15% for commercial property, he estimated a cost to Aviva of £60m, which he considered "manageable". Companies that only offer home insurance are RBS with a 15% share of the market, Lloyds Banking Group with 13% and Legal & General with 4%. This would imply a £9m impact for L&G. RSA's losses are far less than the £120m bill it had to foot after the widespread flood damage in Britain in 2007. Marcus Barnard at Oriel Securities said about RSA's hit: "We don't think the UK losses should come as a particular surprise but are unhelpful." Shares in RSA dropped 1.3p, or 1.2%, to 107p on the news.

webTitle: Bank of England debated £75bn of quantitative easing

fields.standfirst: Bank's monetary policy committee considered pumping even more money into the economy at July's meeting
fields.body:
The Bank of England considered pumping even more money into the economy at this month's monetary policy committee meeting and has left the door open for interest rate cuts in the coming months.

Monetary policy committee (MPC) minutes released on Wednesday show that two policymakers opposed this month's £50bn increase in quantitative easing, where the bank prints money in order to acquire government bonds from financial institutions, but overall the bank backed intervention to kickstart the UK's ailing economy.

The MPC's outlook for the UK has deteriorated since May, the minutes show. The committee thought it was possible the economy would show no growth this year, for the second year running. Despite the progress made at the EU summit on supporting struggling eurozone banks, the committee said "very substantial risks remained". The minutes noted: "There were increasing signs that the threat of a disorderly resolution of the financial tensions in the euro area was affecting growth at home."

The committee discussed increasing the Bank of England's quantitative easing (QE) programme by £75bn, but settled on a £50bn boost to the stimulus – bringing the QE total to £375bn. It also considered the case for cutting interest rates below 0.5%, but decided it was a less attractive tool than QE. It said this decision could be revised after gauging the impact of other policy initiatives in several months' time.

Among these, the committee sounded upbeat about the funding-for-lending scheme (FLS), which will see £80bn of emergency funds used to boost lending to first-time buyers and small companies. The minutes read: "Overall, there were reasons to believe that the scheme would provide a material economic stimulus. But it was too early to judge with any precision what the economic impact would be and when it might be felt."

The MPC members Spencer Dale and Ben Broadbent argued against the increase in QE, citing other measures that had been recently introduced to boost the economy, including FLS. They were also worried that any easing in inflation could prove temporary, with the return of QE therefore threatening to exacerbate any resurgence in prices. Despite those fears, inflation has fallen to its lowest level since late 2009, the Office for National Statistics said this week.

Philip Shaw of Investec said: "What we've seen since the meeting is another sharp fall in inflation. That doesn't necessarily mean there will be more QE, but it lowers any potential barriers to the committee sanctioning further asset purchases if the economy remains subdued." He expects more QE before the end of the year.

Other economists suggest the minutes point towards a rate cut. David Tinsley at BNP Paribas said if there were signs the FLS was working by the November meeting, "they could instead lean more in the direction of a cut in bank rate". He said the rationale would be that an interest rate cut might feed through to households and smaller businesses more directly, "which might complement well with falls in bank funding costs and a greater eagerness of the banking system to supply credit from the lending scheme".

webTitle: AEA Technology slumps 77% after board warns there could be no value for shareholders

fields.standfirst: Company hampered by debt levels and pension obligations fails to reach long term agreement with lender
fields.body:
Could it be the end of the line for shareholders in AEA Technology?

The company, an environmental consultancy spun out of the Atomic Energy Authority in 1994 and floated in 1996, has been struggling with poor trading as well as debt of £34m and pension liabilities of £165.5m.

It has been in talks with its banks and pension trustees, both of whom have apparently been supportive. But despite coming up with a new strategy and business plan, it has not been able to agree a long term solution to its debt and pension problems.

So, with short term financial support from its bank, it has decided to consider "all strategic options to realise value." And here comes the bad news for shareholders:

The board does not envisage there will be offers for the share capital of the company, and the board expects that such options will result in little or no value for shareholders.

The share price reaction was predictable - down 77% to just 0.05p, valuing the business at just £730,000.

webTitle: Publisher Reed Elsevier falls 2% after Europe backs calls for open access to research

fields.standfirst: Worries about open access hit shares but analysts say developments unlikely to impact revenues yet
fields.body:
Reed Elsevier is the biggest faller in the FTSE 100 after the European Commission backed calls for free access to publicly funded research.

The publisher has fallen 11.5p to 521.5p on the EC comments on Tuesday, given it charges subscriptions for its 2000 journals and would seem to be vulnerable to freely available research. But analysts at Exane BNP Paribas said the EU policy was a damp squib:

[It] is unlikely to have any impact on publishers' revenues in the next ten years. The EU is a small player in global research funding - it funds an estimated 8% of all public research spending in the EU27, or less than 3% of global scientific literature.
These developments are in line with our discounted cashflow assumption, which sees open access dominating in 2022 and having no impact before. Even in an open access-dominated world, publishers would continue to generate profit on the value they add to scholarly communications (managing the peer review process and article formatting). In an unlikely worst-case scenario, where the open access pricing pressure is not offset by volumes – Elsevier currently monetizes only one-third of the articles it receives as two-thirds are not accepted for publication – we estimate the market is missing at least 50p per share of value for journal assets. We remain outperform ahead of likely solid first half results due on 26 July.

Elsewhere, Severn Trent has slipped 6p to £16.98 after an in-line trading statement, with rival United Utilities down 10.5p at 687.5p.

webTitle: McDonald's to decline London 2012 tax break

fields.standfirst: Fast-food chain turns down tax exemption for non-UK Games sponsors as campaigners put pressure on others to do the same
fields.body:
McDonald's has bowed to an online campaign and declined an Olympic tax break, just days before the start of the Games.

The move follows a story by Ethical Consumer magazine and pressure from the online campaign group 38 Degrees whose online petition has gathered more than 150,000 signatures. 38 Degrees said this morning: "It's working! McDonald's have said they won't be taking the tax break – but please sign the petition to keep pressure on the other sponsors."

Visa declined to comment on whether it would now refuse the tax break, while British Airways said the tax exemption did not apply to UK companies. Other foreign sponsors, which include Coca-Cola, were in the process of formulating their response, or could not be reached.

New tax rules ushered in as part of London's winning bid to host the Games mean the Olympic site in east London has become the world's latest, albeit temporary, tax haven. These rules mean that so-called partner organisations, such as Coca-Cola and Visa, could pay no tax at all on their earnings from the Games.

McDonald's made clear that the cost of turning down the break would be minimal, as revenue from the Games would be less than 0.1% of its annual sales in the UK. It said in a statement: "We will not be making any corporate income tax exemption claim with respect to any activity concerning our involvement with the London Olympic and Paralympic Games."

Richard Murphy from the Tax Justice Network said: "It is bound to cost the UK tens of millions of pounds to give tax concessions to all the large companies who are operating at the Olympic site. We're giving money away that we need to solve our debt crisis and to preserve essential public services."

The new legislation also exempts foreign nationals working on the games in the UK from paying income tax on any earnings. That includes journalists, representatives of official games bodies, judges and the athletes themselves.

webTitle: Olympics boost helps cut UK unemployment to 2.58m

fields.standfirst: ONS says strong performance of London – with capital registering 61,000 more people in employment over three months – indicates Olympics link
fields.body:
Unemployment has declined for a fourth successive month to its lowest level since last summer – 2.58 million people – as the Olympics helped offset the flat-lining economy and continued turmoil in the eurozone.

The Office for National Statistics said the number of people looking for work had fallen by 65,000 in the three months to May, driving the unemployment rate down to 8.1%, from 8.3% three months earlier. The ONS said the strong performance of London – with the capital registering 61,000 more people in employment over the period – indicated an Olympics link.

Falling unemployment will be welcome news for George Osborne, whose economic policies have come under fierce scrutiny after the International Monetary Fund slashed its growth forecast for the UK this year to just 0.2%.

Howard Archer, of consultancy IHS Global Insight, said: "The labour market is displaying impressive resilience given the very real likelihood that the economy suffered a third successive quarter of contraction in the second quarter." He suggested the boost to employment from the Olympics may have helped to contain unemployment.

The more timely claimant count measure of unemployment, which tracks the number of people receiving Jobseeker's Allowance, gave a conflicting signal, rising by 6,100 in June, to 1.6 million.

However, the ONS said that number may have been boosted by changes to the benefits regime for lone parents and incapacity benefit claimants, some of whom have been shifted to out-of-work benefits in a bid to bring them into the labour force. The number of women claiming JSA increased by 8,000, to 530,700, the highest level since 1995, and the ONS said the rise was likely to have been partly driven by the benefits rule-changes.

Youth unemployment, which the coalition government has sought to tackle through Nick Clegg's Youth Contract, has fallen by 10,000, the ONS said. The jobless rate for 16 to 24-year-olds slipped to 21.9% in the three months to May, from 22.1% three months earlier.

However, the squeeze on households' spending power is continuing, with average incomes rising at an annual rate of 1.5% in May, up just 0.1 percentage points on a month earlier. Inflation has fallen, according to separate figures released by the ONS on Tuesday, but it remains at 2.4%, suggesting many families are still seeing their living standards eroded.

webTitle: Booker reports slowdown in cigarette sales after budget duty rise

fields.standfirst: Company's first quarter sales rise 1.7% despite bad weather, but growth lower than previous three months
fields.body:
A rise in tobacco duty in the budget led to a fall off in cigarette sales, according to Britain's biggest cash and carry wholesaler.

Ahead of its annual meeting Booker said tobacco sales had fallen by 1.7% in the 12 weeks to 22 June, its first quarter. But sales of other products made up the difference - up 3.8% despite the bad weather and the squeeze on consumer spending- and so total sales climbed 1.7% on a like for like basis. However this was a slowdown on the 4.8% increase seen in the fourth quarter, although the company said it was on track to meet full year profit expectations. It added that the £140m acquisition of Makro UK from its German parent was successfully completed at the start of July. The company's shares have climbed 1.45p to 87.7p and analysts were generally positive. Nicola Mallard at Investec said:

It appears that fears the weather would have had a dampening effect on the group's performance in the quarter have perhaps been overplayed. We leave our forecasts unchanged at this early point, but remain buyers with an unchanged target price of 98p.

webTitle: Aer Lingus rejects latest Ryanair takeover bid

fields.standfirst: Irish flag carrier says approach from low-cost rival 'fundamentally undervalues' its business
fields.body:
Aer Lingus has rejected a Ryanair takeover approach for a third time as the Irish flag carrier said the latest bid from its low-cost rival "fundamentally undervalues" the business.

Nearly six years after Aer Lingus turned down the first Ryanair overture, the Dublin-based carrier claimed on Wednesday morning that competition concerns raised by the budget carrier's interest have increased. Ryanair is the biggest shareholder in Aer Lingus with a 29.82% stake and its ambitions have so far been stymied on two regulatory fronts: by a European commission objection to an Aer Lingus/Ryanair combination; and a UK Competition Commission probe into its stake.

Urging shareholders to reject the approach, Aer Lingus said: "Ryanair's 2006 offer was prohibited by the European commission on competition grounds, and your board believes that the reasons for prohibition are now even stronger than before: the number of routes that Ryanair would monopolise has sharply increased. Your board has received legal advice that the European commission is likely once more to prohibit the Ryanair offer, and that this is not therefore a credible offer which is capable of completion."

The latest Ryanair offer values Aer Lingus at €1.30 (£1.02) per share, far below the €2.80 that was offered in the wake of the Aer Lingus flotation in 2006, before the airline industry entered a sustained period of turbulence due to high fuel costs and weak passenger demand following the credit crunch. It then came back in 2008 with an offer of €1.40 per share. Aer Lingus said the latest offer was 31% below the company's gross cash per share of €1.87 – the airline's €1bn cash balance divided by the number of shares. Effectively, Aer Lingus is saying that Ryanair could fund the takeover just from the airline's cash pile.

The second largest shareholder in Aer Lingus, the Irish government, said last month it would consider the Ryanair offer – having rejected approaches more fiercely in the past. The Irish government owns 25% of Aer Lingus, with Irish entrepreneur Denis O'Brien the next largest with a 4% stake. Last month, O'Brien said Ryanair's latest approach undervalued Aer Lingus and may be a ploy to initiate discussions with Abu Dhabi-based Etihad Airways, which owns a 3% percent stake in Aer Lingus.

The Aer Lingus response was triggered by the publication of Ryanair's offer document on Tuesday, in which the low-cost carrier said it would grow jobs at Aer Lingus and raise the flag carrier's passenger numbers from 9.5 million a year to 14 million. Ryanair said those ambitious growth targets would have to be met via more pilots, cabin crew and engineers.

However, it indicated changes to staff terms and conditions as it said a cut in Aer Lingus ticket prices would come with an improvement in "the productivity of [Aer Lingus] staff" in order to hold down costs and maintain profit margins.

Low labour costs are a key factor in Ryanair's business, helping keep down costs, which then feed in to lower fares. Ryanair carried more than 75 million passengers in the year to 31 March and, together with Aer Lingus, accounts for the majority of flights from Dublin airport.

webTitle: Homeserve moves higher despite insurer saying it is not in bid talks, as FTSE edges ahead

fields.standfirst: Troubled group reportedly received private equity interest but says not in discussions
fields.body:
Homeserve, the insurance and repairs company being investigated by the Financial Services Authority for alleged misselling, has jumped nearly 8% despite saying it was not in talks about an offer for the business.

The statement followed a report that Cinven, KKR and Apax had approached Homeserve, although the approach was said to have been dismissed as opportunistic, given recent falls in the company's share price. It was also suggested that chief executive Richard Halpin had been approached about selling his 12% stake. Homeserve said:

Homeserve wishes to clarify that it has not, nor is currently, engaged in any discussions which could lead to a possible offer for the company.

Even so, its shares have jumped 13p to 180p as investors decided it could still be vulnerable to a bid, even though analysts were not so sure. David Brockton at Espirito Santo said:

We continue to view Homeserve's international growth opportunity, supported by its low capital intensive model with a high recurring income base to present an attractive business model. However, the FSA investigation brings Homeserve further material risk of reputational damage and a lengthier than expected review process.
Our 210p fair value is materially above the current volatile share price, but there remains a wide range of possible regulatory outcomes hence we expect the shares to continue trade below the perceived inherent value of the business, particularly now that we know management are not willing to entertain any opportunistic approach for the company.

Still with insurers, RSA Insurance has slipped 1.1p to 107.2p after it said the recent UK floods would cost it at least £50m.

Overall, ahead of UK unemployment figures and the latest Bank of England minutes, the FTSE 100 is up 10.76 points at 5639.85.

Worries about a slowdown in China left miners weaker again, with Rio Tinto down 2o8p to 2888.5p. But BHP Billiton is up 14.5p at 1797.5p following strong growth in iron ore production.

G4S recovered 6p to 246p on vague talk the troubled security firm could be vulnerable to a bid, perhaps from a US rival.
